images.copyright: Snow leopard with her cubs, Spiti Valley, Cold Desert Biosphere Reserve, India (© Oriol Alamany/naturepl.com)
images.title: Snow much love
images.caption: International Day of the Snow Leopard
images.desc: Ever tried spotting a snow leopard in the wild? It's called the 'ghost of the mountains' for a reason—you're more likely to see its pawprints than the big cat itself. But every October 23, the species steps into the spotlight on International Day of the Snow Leopard, a day set aside to protect this elusive predator and its rugged home.

og.title: International Day of the Snow Leopard
og.desc: Ever tried spotting a snow leopard in the wild? It's called the 'ghost of the mountains' for a reason—you're more likely to see its…

images.title: Set in stone
images.caption: Belogradchik Rocks, Bulgaria
images.desc: In Bulgaria, on the western slopes of the Balkan Mountains, the Belogradchik Rocks stand like a natural gallery where every formation tells a tale. Shaped over millions of years by erosion, these sandstone and limestone pillars twist and tower into outlines that locals swear resemble people, animals and even entire scenes. That's why names like 'The Horseman,' 'The Schoolgirl' and 'The Monks' have stuck—it's a landscape where spotting shapes feels a bit like playing nature's version of charades.

og.title: Belogradchik Rocks, Bulgaria
og.desc: In Bulgaria, on the western slopes of the Balkan Mountains, the Belogradchik Rocks stand like a natural gallery where every formation tells…

images.copyright: Oil lamps lit during Diwali (© phive2015/Getty Images)
images.title: Glowing traditions
images.caption: Happy Diwali!
images.desc: Today is Diwali, a festival that celebrates hope, prosperity and the triumph of good over evil. It marks Rama's return to Ayodhya after defeating the demon king Ravana, and honours the goddess Lakshmi, believed to bring wealth and well-being into homes, while some communities worship the goddess, Kali. Families clean and decorate their homes, exchange sweets (or mithai), and gather for prayers—filling neighbourhoods with an atmosphere of joy. Meanwhile, markets bustle with shoppers buying gifts and new clothes, while fireworks light up the sky. Central to the festival are diyas—small oil lamps whose flames symbolise the triumph of light over darkness and the promise of new beginnings.

og.title: Happy Diwali!
og.desc: Today is Diwali, a festival that celebrates hope, prosperity and the triumph of good over evil. It marks Rama's return to Ayodhya after…

images.copyright: Hoffmann's two-toed sloth, Ecuador (© Murray Cooper/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Life in the slow lane
images.caption: Hoffmann's two-toed sloth, Ecuador
images.desc: How good would it feel if you could just hang out and do absolutely nothing all day? That's exactly what sloths do. The Hoffmann's two-toed sloth, featured in today's image, is a prime example of this slow-paced lifestyle. Their deliberate movements conserve energy, avoid predators and even allow algae to grow on their fur, creating green camouflage among the canopy.

og.title: Hoffmann's two-toed sloth, Ecuador
og.desc: How good would it feel if you could just hang out and do absolutely nothing all day? That's exactly what sloths do. The Hoffmann's two-toed…

images.copyright: Apples ready for harvest, Minnesota, United States (© Tammi Mild/Getty Images)
images.title: Sweet on science
images.caption: Apples ready for harvest, Minnesota, United States
images.desc: In Minnesota, United States, autumn carries more than crimson leaves—it brings the crisp promise of apple season. From mid-August through late October, orchards across the state open their rows of Honeycrisp, Haralson and dozens of other cultivars, each bred for flavour, resilience and charm. Today's image captures that moment: branches heavy with ripe fruit, ready for harvest. This land takes its apples seriously. The state apple, the Honeycrisp, now a world favourite, was born in the orchards of the University of Minnesota, where scientists have cultivated apples for over a century.

og.title: Apples ready for harvest, Minnesota, United States

images.copyright: Neolithic site of Silbury Hill, Tilshead, Wiltshire, England (© dbstockphoto/Getty Images)
images.title: The hill that remembers
images.caption: Neolithic site of Silbury Hill, Tilshead, Wiltshire, England
images.desc: Across ages, archaeology has urged us to look beneath the surface, unearthing stories buried in the land. At first glance, Silbury Hill in Wiltshire, England, may seem like a simple slope in the countryside. However, it conceals a 4,500-year-old Neolithic enigma. Starting around 2400 BCE, chalk was locally quarried, transported and compacted by hand, layer by layer, over generations. The result is the tallest prehistoric mound in Europe, built entirely by human effort, rising to almost 40 metres.

og.title: Neolithic site of Silbury Hill, Tilshead, Wiltshire, England
og.desc: Across ages, archaeology has urged us to look beneath the surface, unearthing stories buried in the land. At first glance, Silbury Hill in…

images.copyright: Rock River Falls, Upper Peninsula, Michigan, United States (© Matt Anderson Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Falling for Michigan
images.caption: Rock River Falls, Upper Peninsula, Michigan, United States
images.desc: Nestled within Michigan's Rock River Canyon Wilderness in the United States, Rock River Falls emerges amid a landscape shaped by glaciers, dense woods and layers of history. In the Upper Peninsula, humans have left their traces for millennia: Indigenous Algonquian-speaking peoples were followed by French and British explorers and waves of Finnish, Swedish and French-Canadian immigrants settled there during the 19th-century mining and logging booms. Today, this sparsely populated region hosts barely 3% of Michigan's residents, cradling its forests and waterfalls in near-natural serenity.

images.copyright: Eurasian lynx, Siberia (© Mario Plechaty Photograph/Shutterstock)
images.title: The phantom cat
images.caption: Eurasian lynx
images.desc: Think of a cat that can vanish into the forest without a sound—that's the Eurasian lynx. With its tufted ears and a piercing gaze, this feline is the largest of the four lynx species. Stretching over 100 centimetres in length and standing as tall as 75 centimetres at the shoulder, the Eurasian lynx is built for power and precision. Its padded paws aren't just for sneaking; they act like snowshoes, spreading its weight so it can chase down prey in deep winter drifts. Mostly a nocturnal hunter, it spends its days tucked away in thickets or rocky dens, venturing out under the cover of darkness to stalk deer, hares and squirrels.
